a traitor live!

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.ab: Stay, countrymen.

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.ab: Peace there! hear the noble Antony.

sp.speaker: Second Citizen
sp.ab: We'll hear him, we'll follow him, we'll die with him.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Good friends, sweet friends, let me not stir you up
To such a sudden flood of mutiny.
They that have done this deed are honourable:
What private griefs they have, alas, I know not,
That made them do it: they are wise and honourable,
And will, no doubt, with reasons answer you.
I come not, friends, to steal away your hearts:
I am no orator, as Brutus is;
But, as you know me all, a plain blunt man,
That love my friend; and that they know full well
That gave me public leave to speak of him:
For I have neither wit, nor words, nor worth,
Action, nor utterance, nor the power of speech,
To stir men's blood: I only speak right on;
I tell you that which you yourselves do know;
Show you sweet Caesar's wounds, poor poor dumb mouths,
And bid them speak for me: but were I Brutus,
And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony
Would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue
In every wound of Caesar that should move
The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: We'll mutiny.

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.l: We'll burn the house of Brutus.

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.l: Away, then! come, seek the conspirators.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Yet hear me, countrymen; yet hear me speak.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Peace, ho! Hear Antony. Most noble Antony!

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Why, friends, you go to do you know not what:
Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves?
Alas, you know not: I must tell you, then:
You have forgot the will I told you of.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Most true. The will! Let's stay and hear the will.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Here is the will, and under Caesar's seal.
To every Roman citizen he gives,
To every several man, seventy-five drachmas.

sp.speaker: Second Citizen
sp.l: Most noble Caesar! We'll revenge his death.

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.l: O royal Caesar!

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Hear me with patience.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Peace, ho!

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Moreover, he hath left you all his walks,
His private arbours and new-planted orchards,
On this side Tiber; he hath left them you,
And to your heirs for ever, common pleasures,
To walk abroad, and recreate yourselves.
Here was a Caesar! when comes such another?

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.l: Never, never! Come, away, away!
We'll burn his body in the holy place,
And with the brands fire the traitors' houses.
Take up the body.

sp.speaker: Second Citizen
sp.ab: Go fetch fire.

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.ab: Pluck down benches.

sp.speaker: Fourth Citizen
sp.ab: Pluck down forms, windows, any thing.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Now let it work. Mischief, thou art afoot,
Take thou what course thou wilt! Enter a Servant. How now, fellow!

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir, Octavius is already come to Rome.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: He and Lepidus are at Caesar's house.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: And thither will I straight to visit him:
He comes upon a wish. Fortune is merry,
And in this mood will give us any thing.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I heard him say, Brutus and Cassius
Are rid like madmen through the gates of Rome.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Belike they had some notice of the people,
How I had moved them. Bring me to Octavius. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cinna
sp.l: I dreamt to-night that I did feast with Caesar,
And things unluckily charge my fantasy:
I have no will to wander forth of doors,
Yet something leads me forth. Enter Citizens.

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.ab: What is your name?

sp.speaker: Second Citizen
sp.ab: Whither are you going?

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.ab: Where do you dwell?

sp.speaker: Fourth Citizen
sp.ab: Are you a married man or a bachelor?

sp.speaker: Second Citizen
sp.ab: Answer every man directly.

sp.speaker: Fourth Citizen
sp.ab: Ay, and briefly.

sp.speaker: Fourth Citizen
sp.ab: Ay, and wisely.

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.ab: Ay, and truly, you were best.

sp.speaker: Cinna
sp.ab: What is my name? Whither am I going? Where do I
dwell? Am I a married man or a bachelor? Then,
to answer every man directly and briefly, wisely and
truly: wisely I say, I am a bachelor.

sp.speaker: Second Citizen
sp.ab: That's as much as to say, they are fools that
marry: you'll bear me a bang for that, I fear.
Proceed; directly.

sp.speaker: Cinna
sp.ab: Directly, I am going to Caesar's funeral.

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.ab: As a friend or an enemy?

sp.speaker: Cinna
sp.ab: As a friend.

sp.speaker: Second Citizen
sp.ab: That matter is answered directly.

sp.speaker: Fourth Citizen
sp.ab: For your dwelling, briefly.

sp.speaker: Cinna
sp.ab: Briefly, I dwell by the Capitol.

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.ab: Your name, sir, truly.

sp.speaker: Cinna
sp.ab: Truly, my name is Cinna.

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.ab: Tear him to pieces; he's a conspirator.

sp.speaker: Cinna
sp.ab: I am Cinna the poet, I am Cinna the poet.

sp.speaker: Fourth Citizen
sp.ab: Tear him for his bad verses, tear him for his bad
verses.

sp.speaker: Cinna
sp.ab: I am not Cinna the conspirator.

sp.speaker: Fourth Citizen
sp.ab: It is no matter, his name's Cinna; pluck but his name
out of his heart, and turn him going.

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.ab: Tear him, tear him! Come, brands, ho! firebrands:
to Brutus', to Cassius'; burn all: some to Decius'
house, and some to Casca's; some to Ligarius': away,
go!

div.head: Act 4, Scene 1
div.stage: ANTONY, OCTAVIUS, and LEPIDUS, seated at a table.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: These many, then, shall die; their names are pricked.

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: Your brother too must die; consent you, Lepidus?

sp.speaker: Lepidus
sp.l: I do consent

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: Prick him down, Antony.

sp.speaker: Lepidus
sp.l: Upon condition Publius shall not live,
Who is your sister's son, Mark Antony.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: He shall not live; look, with a spot I damn him.
But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar's house;
Fetch the will hither, and we shall determine
How to cut off some charge in legacies.

sp.speaker: Lepidus
sp.l: What, shall I find you here?

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: Or here, or at the Capitol. Exit Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: This is a slight unmeritable man,
Meet to be sent on errands: is it fit,
The threefold world divided, he should stand
One of the three to share it?

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: So you thought him;
And took his voice who should be pricked to die,
In our black sentence and proscription.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Octavius, I have seen more days than you:
And though we lay these honours on this man,
To ease ourselves of divers slanderous loads,
He shall but bear them as the ass bears gold,
To groan and sweat under the business,
Either led or driven, as we point the way;
And having brought our treasure where we will,
Then take we down his load, and turn him off,
Like to the empty ass, to shake his ears,
And graze in commons.

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: You may do your will;
But he's a tried and valiant soldier.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: So is my horse, Octavius; and for that
I do appoint him store of provender:
It is a creature that I teach to fight,
To wind, to stop, to run directly on,
His corporal motion governed by my spirit.
And, in some taste, is Lepidus but so;
He must be taught and trained and bid go forth;
A barren-spirited fellow; one that feeds
On objects, arts and imitations,
Which, out of use and staled by other men,
Begin his fashion: do not talk of him
But as a property. And now, Octavius,
Listen great things: Brutus and Cassius
Are levying powers: we must straight make head:
Therefore let our alliance be combined,
Our best friends made, our means stretched;
And let us presently go sit in council,
How covert matters may be best disclosed,
And open perils surest answered.

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: Let us do so: for we are at the stake,
And bayed about with many enemies;
And some that smile have in their hearts, I fear,
Millions of mischiefs. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 2
div.stage: Camp near Sardis. Before Brutus's tent.
Drum. Enter BRUTUS, LUCILIUS, LUCIUS, and Soldiers; TITINIUS and PINDARUS meeting them.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Stand, ho!

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.l: Give the word, ho! and stand.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: What now, Lucilius! is Cassius near?

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.l: He is at hand; and Pindarus is come
To do you salutation from his master.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: He greets me well. Your master, Pindarus,
In his own change, or by ill officers,
Hath given me some worthy cause to wish
Things done, undone: but, if he be at hand,
I shall be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Pindarus
sp.l: I do not doubt
But that my noble master will appear
Such as he is, full of regard and honour.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: He is not doubted. A word, Lucilius;
How he received you, let me be resolved.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.l: With courtesy and with respect enough;
But not with such familiar instances,
Nor with such free and friendly conference,
As he hath used of old.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Thou hast described
A hot friend cooling: ever note, Lucilius,
When love begins to sicken and decay,
It useth an enforced ceremony.
There are no tricks in plain and simple faith;
But hollow men, like horses hot at hand,
Make gallant show and promise of their mettle;
But when they should endure the bloody spur,
They fall their crests, and, like deceitful jades,
Sink in the trial. Comes his army on?

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.l: They mean this night in Sardis to be quartered;
The greater part, the horse in general,
Are come with Cassius.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Hark! he is arrived. Low march within.
March gently on to meet him. Enter CASSIUS and his powers.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Stand, ho!

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Stand, ho! Speak the word along.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: Stand!

sp.speaker: Second Soldier
sp.l: Stand!

sp.speaker: Third Soldier
sp.l: Stand!

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Most noble brother, you have done me wrong.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Judge me, you gods! wrong I mine enemies?
And, if not so, how should I wrong a brother?

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Brutus, this sober form of yours hides wrongs;
And when you do them

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Cassius, be content;
Speak your griefs softly: I do know you well.
Before the eyes of both our armies here,
Which should perceive nothing but love from us,
Let us not wrangle: bid them move away;
Then in my tent, Cassius, enlarge your griefs,
And I will give you audience.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Pindarus,
Bid our commanders lead their charges off
A little from this ground.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Lucius, do you the like; and let no man
Come to our tent till we have done our conference.
Let Lucilius and Titinius guard our door. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: That you have wronged me doth appear in this:
You have condemned and noted Lucius Pella
For taking bribes here of the Sardians;
Wherein my letters, praying on his side,
Because I knew the man was slighted off.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: You wronged yourself to write in such a case.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: In such a time as this it is not meet
That every nice offence should bear his comment.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Let me tell you, Cassius, you yourself
Are much condemned to have an itching palm;
To sell and mart your offices for gold
To undeservers.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: I an itching palm!
You know that you are Brutus that speaks this,
Or, by the gods, this speech were else your last.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: The name of Cassius honours this corruption,
And chastisement doth therefore hide his head,

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Chastisement!

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Remember March, the ides of March remember:
Did not great Julius bleed for justice' sake?
What villain touched his body, that did stab,
And not for justice? What, shall one of us,
That struck the foremost man of all this world
But for supporting robbers, shall we now
Contaminate our fingers with base bribes,
And sell the mighty space of our large honours
For so much trash as may be grasped thus?
I had rather be a dog, and bay the moon,
Than such a Roman.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Brutus, bait not me;
I'll not endure it: you forget yourself,
To hedge me in; I am a soldier, I,
Older in practice, abler than yourself
To make conditions.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Go to; you are not, Cassius.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: I say you are not.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Urge me no more, I shall forget myself;
Have mind upon your health, tempt me no further.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Away, slight man!

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Hear me, for I will speak.
Must I give way and room to your rash choler?
Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: O ye gods, ye gods must I endure all this?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: All this! ay, more: fret till your proud heart break;
Go show your slaves how choleric you are,
And make your bondmen tremble. Must I bouge?
Must I observe you? must I stand and crouch
Under your testy humour? By the gods
You shall digest the venom of your spleen,
Though it do split you; for, from this day forth,
I'll use you for my mirth, yea, for my laughter,
When you are waspish.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Is it come to this?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: You say you are a better soldier:
Let it appear so; make your vaunting true,
And it shall please me well: for mine own part,
I shall be glad to learn of noble men.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: You wrong me every way; you wrong me, Brutus;
I said, an elder soldier, not a better:
Did I say “better”?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: If you did, I care not.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: When Caesar lived, he durst not thus have moved me.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Peace, peace! you durst not so have tempted him.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: I durst not!

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: What, durst not tempt him!

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: For your life you durst not.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Do not presume too much upon my love;
I may do that I shall be sorry for.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: You have done that you should be sorry for.
There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats,
For I am armed so strong in honesty
That they pass by me as the idle wind,
Which I respect not. I did send to you
For certain sums of gold, which you denied me:
For I can raise no money by vile means:
By heaven, I had rather coin my heart,
And drop my blood for drachmas, than to wring
From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash
By any indirection: I did send
To you for gold to pay my legions,
Which you denied me: was that done like Cassius?
Should I have answered Caius Cassius so?
When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous,
To lock such rascal counters from his friends,
Be ready, gods, with all your thunderbolts;
Dash him to pieces!

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: I denied you not.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: You did.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: I did not: he was but a fool that brought
My answer back. Brutus hath rived my heart:
A friend should bear his friend's infirmities,
But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: I do not, till you practise them on me.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: You love me not.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: I do not like your faults.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: A friendly eye could never see such faults.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: A flatterer's would not, though they do appear
As huge as high Olympus.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Come, Antony, and young Octavius, come,
Revenge yourselves alone on Cassius,
For Cassius is aweary of the world;
Hated by one he loves; braved by his brother;
Checked like a bondman; all his faults observed,
Set in a note-book, learned, and conned by rote,
To cast into my teeth. O, I could weep
My spirit from mine eyes! There is my dagger,
And here my naked breast; within, a heart
Dearer than Pluto's mine, richer than gold:
If that thou be'st a Roman, take it forth;
I, that denied thee gold, will give my heart:
Strike, as thou didst at Caesar; for, I know,
When thou didst hate him worst, thou lovedst him better
Than ever thou lovedst Cassius.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Sheathe your dagger:
Be angry when you will, it shall have scope;
Do what you will, dishonour shall be humour.
O Cassius, you are yoked with a lamb
That carries anger as the flint bears fire;
Who, much enforced, shows a hasty spark,
And straight is cold again.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Hath Cassius lived
To be but mirth and laughter to his Brutus,
When grief, and blood ill-tempered, vexeth him?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: When I spoke that, I was ill-tempered too.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Do you confess so much? Give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: And my heart too.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: O Brutus!

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Have not you love enough to bear with me,
When that rash humour which my mother gave me
Makes me forgetful?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Yes, Cassius; and, from henceforth,
When you are overearnest with your Brutus,
He'll think your mother chides, and leave you so.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: Let me go in to see the generals;
There is some grudge between 'em, 'tis not meet
They be alone.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.l: You shall not come to them.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: Nothing but death shall stay me. Enter Poet, followed by LUCILIUS, TITINIUS, and LUCIUS.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: How now! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.l: For shame, you generals! what do you mean?

lg.l: Love, and be friends, as two such men should be;
For I have seen more years, I'm sure, than ye.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Ha, ha! how vilely doth this cynic rhyme!

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Get you hence, sirrah; saucy fellow, hence!

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Bear with him, Brutus; 'tis his fashion.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: I'll know his humour, when he knows his time:
What should the wars do with these jigging fools?
Companion, hence!

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Away, away, be gone. Exit Poet.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Lucilius and Titinius, bid the commanders
Prepare to lodge their companies to-night.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: And come yourselves, and bring Messala with you
Immediately to us. Exeunt Lucilius and Titinius.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Lucius, a bowl of wine! Exit Lucius.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: I did not think you could have been so angry.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Of your philosophy you make no use,
If you give place to accidental evils.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: No man bears sorrow better. Portia is dead.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Ha! Portia!

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: She is dead.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: How scaped I killing when I crossed you so?
O insupportable and touching loss!
Upon what sickness?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Impatient of my absence,
And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony
Have made themselves so strong: for with her death
That tidings came; with this she fell distract,
And, her attendants absent, swallowed fire.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: And died so?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Even so.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: O ye immortal gods! Re-enter Lucius, with wine and taper.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Speak no more of her. Give me a bowl of wine.
In this I bury all unkindness, Cassius.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge.
Fill, Lucius, till the wine o'erswell the cup;
I cannot drink too much of Brutus' love.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Come in, Titinius! Exit Lucius. Re-enter TITINIUS, with MESSALA. Welcome, good Messala.
Now sit we close about this taper here,
And call in question our necessities.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Portia, art thou gone?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: No more, I pray you.
Messala, I have here received letters,
That young Octavius and Mark Antony
Come down upon us with a mighty power,
Bending their expedition toward Philippi.

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: With what addition?

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: That by proscription and bills of outlawry,
Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus,
Have put to death an hundred senators.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Therein our letters do not well agree;
Mine speak of seventy senators that died
By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Cicero one!

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: Cicero is dead,
And by that order of proscription.
Had you your letters from your wife, my lord?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: No, Messala.

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: Nor nothing in your letters writ of her?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Nothing, Messala.

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: That, methinks, is strange.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Why ask you? hear you aught of her in yours?

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Now, as you are a Roman, tell me true.

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell:
For certain she is dead, and by strange manner.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Why, farewell, Portia. We must die, Messala:
With meditating that she must die once,
I have the patience to endure it now.

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: Even so great men great losses should endure.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: I have as much of this in art as you,
But yet my nature could not bear it so.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Well, to our work alive. What do you think
Of marching to Philippi presently?

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: I do not think it good.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Your reason?

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: This it is:
'Tis better that the enemy seek us:
So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers,
Doing himself offence; whilst we, lying still,
Are full of rest, defence, and nimbleness.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Good reasons must, of force, give place to better.
The people 'twixt Philippi and this ground
Do stand but in a forced affection;
For they have grudged us contribution:
The enemy, marching along by them,
By them shall make a fuller number up,
Come on refreshed, new-added, and encouraged;
From which advantage shall we cut him off,
If at Philippi we do face him there,
These people at our back.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Hear me, good brother.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Under your pardon. You must note beside,
That we have tried the utmost of our friends,
Our legions are brimful, our cause is ripe:
The enemy increaseth every day;
We, at the height, are ready to decline.
There is a tide in the affairs of men,
Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune;
Omitted, all the voyage of their life
Is bound in shallows and in miseries.
On such a full sea are we now afloat;
And we must take the current when it serves,
Or lose our ventures.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Then, with your will, go on;
We'll along ourselves, and meet them at Philippi.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: The deep of night is crept upon our talk,
And nature must obey necessity;
Which we will niggard with a little rest.
There is no more to say?

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: No more. Good night:
Early to-morrow will we rise, and hence.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Lucius! Enter Lucius. My gown. Exit Lucius. Farewell, good Messala:
Good night, Titinius. Noble, noble Cassius,
Good night, and good repose.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: O my dear brother!
This was an ill beginning of the night:
Never come such division 'tween our souls!
Let it not, Brutus.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Every thing is well.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Good night, my lord.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Good night, good brother.

sp.speaker: Titinius and Messala
sp.l: Good night, Lord Brutus.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Farewell, every one. Exeunt all but Brutus. Re-enter Lucius, with the gown.
Give me the gown. Where is thy instrument?

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Here in the tent.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: What, thou speak'st drowsily?
Poor knave, I blame thee not; thou art o'erwatched.
Call Claudio and some other of my men:
I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Varrus and Claudio! Enter Varrus and claudio.

sp.speaker: Varro
sp.l: Calls my lord?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep
It may be I shall raise you by and by
On business to my brother Cassius.

sp.speaker: Varro
sp.l: So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: I will not have it so: lie down, good sirs;
It may be I shall otherwise bethink me.
Look, Lucius, here's the book I sought for so;
I put it in the pocket of my gown. Var. and Clau. lie down.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: I was sure your lordship did not give it me.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Bear with me, good boy, I am much forgetful.
Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile,
And touch thy instrument a strain or two?

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Ay, my lord, an't please you.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: It does, my boy:
I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: It is my duty, sir.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: I should not urge thy duty past thy might;
I know young bloods look for a time of rest.

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: I have slept, my lord, already.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: It was well done; and thou shalt sleep again;
I will not hold thee long: if I do live,
I will be good to thee. Music, and a song.
This is a sleepy tune. O murderous slumber,
Lay'st thou thy leaden mace upon my boy,
That plays thee music? Gentle knave, good night;
I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee:
If thou dost nod, thou break'st thy instrument;
I'll take it from thee; and, good boy, good night.
Let me see, let me see; is not the leaf turned down
Where I left reading? Here it is, I think. Enter the Ghost of CAESAR.
How ill this taper burns! Ha! who comes here?
I think it is the weakness of mine eyes
That shapes this monstrous apparition.
It comes upon me. Art thou any thing?
Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil,
That makest my blood cold and my hair to stare?
Speak to me what thou art.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Thy evil spirit, Brutus.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Why comest thou?

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Well; then I shall see thee again?

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Ay, at Philippi.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Why, I will see thee at Philippi, then. Exit Ghost.
Now I have taken heart thou vanishest:
Ill spirit, I would hold more talk with thee.
Boy, Lucius! Varrus! Claudio! Sirs, awake!
Claudio!

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: The strings, my lord, are false.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: He thinks he still is at his instrument.
Lucius, awake!

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Didst thou dream, Lucius, that thou so criedst out?

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: My lord, I do not know that I did cry.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Yes that thou didst: didst thou see any thing?

sp.speaker: Lucius
sp.l: Nothing, my lord.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Sleep again, Lucius. Sirrah Claudio!
To Var. Fellow thou, awake!

sp.speaker: Varro
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Why did you so cry out, sirs, in your sleep?

sp.speaker: Varro and Claudio
sp.l: Did we, my lord?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Ay: saw you any thing?

sp.speaker: Varro
sp.l: No, my lord, I saw nothing.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Nor I, my lord.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Go and commend me to my brother Cassius;
Bid him set on his powers betimes before,
And we will follow.

sp.speaker: Varro and Claudio
sp.l: It shall be done, my lord. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, and their army.

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: Now, Antony, our hopes are answered:
You said the enemy would not come down,
But keep the hills and upper regions;
It proves not so: their battles are at hand;
They mean to warn us at Philippi here,
Answering before we do demand of them.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know
Wherefore they do it: they could be content
To visit other places; and come down
With fearful bravery, thinking by this face
To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage;
But 'tis not so. Enter a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Prepare you, generals:
The enemy comes on in gallant show;
Their bloody sign of battle is hung out,
And something to be done immediately.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Octavius, lead your battle softly on,
Upon the left hand of the even field.

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: Upon the right hand I; keep thou the left.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Why do you cross me in this exigent?

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: I do not cross you; but I will do so. March. Drum. Enter BRUTUS, CASSIUS, and their Army; LUCILIUS, TITINIUS, MESSALA, and others.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: They stand, and would have parley.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Stand fast, Titinius: we must out and talk.

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: No, Caesar, we will answer on their charge.
Make forth; the generals would have some words.

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: Stir not until the signal.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Words before blows: is it so, countrymen?

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: Not that we love words better, as you do.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words:
Witness the hole you made in Caesar's heart,
Crying “Long live! hail, Caesar!”

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Antony,
The posture of your blows are yet unknown;
But for your words, they rob the Hybla bees,
And leave them honeyless.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Not stingless too.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: O, yes, and soundless too;
For you have stol'n their buzzing, Antony,
And very wisely threat before you sting.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Villains, you did not so, when your vile daggers
Hacked one another in the sides of Caesar:
You showed your teeth like apes, and fawned like hounds,
And bowed like bondmen, kissing Caesar's feet;
Whilst damned Casca, like a cur, behind
Struck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers!

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Flatterers! Now, Brutus, thank yourself:
This tongue had not offended so to-day,
If Cassius might have ruled.

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: Come, come, the cause: if arguing make us sweat,
The proof of it will turn to redder drops.
Look;
I draw a sword against conspirators;
When think you that the sword goes up again?
Never, till Caesar's three and thirty wounds
Be well avenged; or till another Caesar
Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Caesar, thou canst not die by traitors' hands,
Unless thou bring'st them with thee.

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: So I hope;
I was not born to die on Brutus' sword.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: O, if thou wert the noblest of thy strain,
Young man, thou couldst not die more honourable.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: A peevish schoolboy, worthless of such honour,
Joined with a masker and a reveller!

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Old Cassius still!

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: Come, Antony, away!
Defiance, traitors, hurl we in your teeth:
If you dare fight to-day, come to the field;
If not, when you have stomachs. Exeunt Octavius, Antony, and their army.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Why, now, blow wind, swell billow and swim bark!
The storm is up, and all is on the hazard.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Ho, Lucilius! hark, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.l: My lord? Brutus and Lucilius converse apart.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Messala!

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: What says my general?

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Messala,
This is my birthday; as this very day
Was Cassius born. Give me thy hand, Messala:
Be thou my witness that against my will,
As Pompey was, am I compelled to set
Upon one battle all our liberties.
You know that I held Epicurus strong
And his opinion: now I change my mind,
And partly credit things that do presage.
Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign
Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perched,
Gorging and feeding from our soldiers' hands;
Who to Philippi here consorted us:
This morning are they fled away and gone;
And in their steads do ravens, crows and kites,
Fly o'er our heads and downward look on us,
As we were sickly prey: their shadows seem
A canopy most fatal, under which
Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost.

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: Believe not so.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: I but believe it partly;
For I am fresh of spirit and resolved
To meet all perils very constantly.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Even so, Lucilius.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Now, most noble Brutus,
The gods to-day stand friendly, that we may,
Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age!
But since the affairs of men rests still incertain,
Let's reason with the worst that may befall.
If we do lose this battle, then is this
The very last time we shall speak together:
What are you then determined to do?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Even by the rule of that philosophy
By which I did blame Cato for the death
Which he did give himself, I know not how,
But I do find it cowardly and vile,
For fear of what might fall, so to prevent
The time of life: arming myself with patience
To stay the providence of some high powers
That govern us below.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Then, if we lose this battle,
You are contented to be led in triumph
Thorough the streets of Rome?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: No, Cassius, no: think not, thou noble Roman,
That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome;
He bears too great a mind. But this same day
Must end that work the ides of March begun;
And whether we shall meet again I know not.
Therefore our everlasting farewell take:
For ever, and for ever, farewell, Cassius!
If we do meet again, why, we shall smile;
If not, why then, this parting was well made.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: For ever, and for ever, farewell, Brutus!
If we do meet again, we'll smile indeed;
If not, 'tis true this parting was well made.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Why, then, lead on. O, that a man might know
The end of this day's business ere it come!
But it sufficeth that the day will end,
And then the end is known. Come, ho! away! Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 2
div.stage: The same. The field of battle.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills
Unto the legions on the other side. Loud alarum.
Let them set on at once; for I perceive
But cold demeanour in Octavio's wing,
And sudden push gives them the overthrow.
Ride, ride, Messala: let them all come down. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: O, look, Titinius, look, the villains fly!
Myself have to mine own turned enemy:
This ensign here of mine was turning back;
I slew the coward, and did take it from him.

sp.speaker: Titinius
sp.l: O Cassius, Brutus gave the word too early;
Who, having some advantage on Octavius,
Took it too eagerly: his soldiers fell to spoil,
Whilst we by Antony are all enclosed. Enter PINDARUS.

sp.speaker: Pindarus
sp.l: Fly further off, my lord, fly further off;
Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord:
Fly, therefore, noble Cassius, fly far off.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: This hill is far enough. Look, look, Titinius;
Are those my tents where I perceive the fire?

sp.speaker: Titinius
sp.l: They are, my lord.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Titinius, if thou lovest me,
Mount thou my horse, and hide thy spurs in him,
Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops,
And here again; that I may rest assured
Whether yond troops are friend or enemy.

sp.speaker: Titinius
sp.l: I will be here again, even with a thought. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Go, Pindarus, get higher on that hill;
My sight was ever thick; regard Titinius,
And tell me what thou notest about the field. Pindarus ascends the hill.
This day I breathed first: time is come round,
And where I did begin, there shall I end;
My life is run his compass. Sirrah, what news?

sp.speaker: Pindarus
sp.l: O my lord!

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: What news?

sp.speaker: Pindarus
sp.l: Titinius is enclosed round about
With horsemen, that make to him on the spur;
Yet he spurs on. Now they are almost on him.
Now, Titinius! Now some light. O, he lights too.
He's ta'en. Shout. And, hark! they shout for joy.

sp.speaker: Cassius
sp.l: Come down, behold no more.
O coward that I am, to live so long,
To see my best friend ta'en before my face! PINDARUS descends.
Come hither, sirrah:
In Parthia did I take thee prisoner;
And then I swore thee, saving of thy life,
That whatsoever I did bid thee do,
Thou shouldst attempt it. Come now, keep thine oath;
Now be a freeman: and with this good sword,
That ran through Caesar's bowels, search this bosom.
Stand not to answer: here, take thou the hilts;
And, when my face is covered, as 'tis now,
Guide thou the sword. Pindarus stabs him. Caesar, thou art revenged,
Even with the sword that killed thee. Dies.

sp.speaker: Pindarus
sp.l: So, I am free; yet would not so have been,
Durst I have done my will. O Cassius,
Far from this country Pindarus shall run,
Where never Roman shall take note of him. Exit. Re-enter TITINIUS with MESSALA.

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: It is but change, Titinius; for Octavius
Is overthrown by noble Brutus' power,
As Cassius' legions are by Antony.

sp.speaker: Titinius
sp.l: These tidings will well comfort Cassius.

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: Where did you leave him?

sp.speaker: Titinius
sp.l: All disconsolate,
With Pindarus his bondman, on this hill.

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: Is not that he that lies upon the ground?

sp.speaker: Titinius
sp.l: He lies not like the living. O my heart!

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: Is not that he?

sp.speaker: Titinius
sp.l: No, this was he, Messala,
But Cassius is no more. O setting sun,
As in thy red rays thou dost sink to-night,
So in his red blood Cassius' day is set;
The sun of Rome is set! Our day is gone;
Clouds, dews, and dangers come; our deeds are done!
Mistrust of my success hath done this deed.

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: Mistrust of good success hath done this deed.
O hateful error, melancholy's child,
Why dost thou show to the apt thoughts of men
The things that are not? O error, soon conceived,
Thou never comest unto a happy birth,
But kill'st the mother that engendered thee!

sp.speaker: Titinius
sp.l: What, Pindarus! where art thou, Pindarus?

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet
The noble Brutus, thrusting this report
Into his ears; I may say, thrusting it;
For piercing steel and darts envenomed
Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus
As tidings of this sight.

sp.speaker: Titinius
sp.l: Hie you, Messala,
And I will seek for Pindarus the while. Exit Messala.
Why didst thou send me forth, brave Cassius?
Did I not meet thy friends? and did not they
Put on my brows this wreath of victory,
And bid me give it thee? Didst thou not hear their shouts?
Alas, thou hast misconstrued every thing!
But, hold thee, take this garland on thy brow;
Thy Brutus bid me give it thee, and I
Will do his bidding. Brutus, come apace,
And see how I regarded Caius Cassius.
By your leave, gods: this is a Roman's part:
Come, Cassius' sword, and find Titinius' heart. Kills himself. Alarum. Re-enter MESSALA, with BRUTUS, young CATO, STRATO, VOLUMNIUS, and LUCILIUS.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Where, where, Messala, doth his body lie?

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: Lo, yonder, and Titinius mourning it.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Titinius' face is upward.

sp.speaker: Young Cato
sp.l: He is slain.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: O Julius Caesar, thou art mighty yet!
Thy spirit walks abroad, and turns our swords
In our own proper entrails. Low alarums.

sp.speaker: Young Cato
sp.l: Brave Titinius!
Look, whether he have not crowned dead Cassius!

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Are yet two Romans living such as these?
The last of all the Romans, fare thee well!
It is impossible that ever Rome
Should breed thy fellow. Friends, I owe more tears
To this dead man than you shall see me pay.
I shall find time, Cassius, I shall find time.
Come, therefore, and to Thasos send his body:
His funerals shall not be in our camp,
Lest it discomfort us. Lucilius, come;
And come, young Cato; let us to the field.
Labeo and Flavius, set our battles on:
'Tis three o'clock; and, Romans, yet ere night
We shall try fortune in a second fight. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 4
div.stage: Alarum. Enter fighting, soldiers of both armies; then BRUTUS, young CATO, LUCILIUS, and others.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Yet, countrymen, O, yet hold up your heads!

sp.speaker: Young Cato
sp.l: What bastard doth not? Who will go with me?
I will proclaim my name about the field:
I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!
A foe to tyrants, and my country's friend;
I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I;
Brutus, my country's friend; know me for Brutus! Exit.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.l: O young and noble Cato, art thou down?
Why, now thou diest as bravely as Titinius;
And mayst be honoured, being Cato's son.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: Yield, or thou diest.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.l: Only I yield to die:
There is so much that thou wilt kill me straight; Offering money.
Kill Brutus, and be honoured in his death.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: We must not. A noble prisoner!

sp.speaker: Second Soldier
sp.l: Room, ho! Tell Antony, Brutus is ta'en.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: I'll tell the news. Here comes the general. Enter ANTONY.
Brutus is ta'en, Brutus is ta'en, my lord.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.l: Safe, Antony; Brutus is safe enough:
I dare assure thee that no enemy
Shall ever take alive the noble Brutus:
The gods defend him from so great a shame!
When you do find him, or alive or dead,
He will be found like Brutus, like himself.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: This is not Brutus, friend; but, I assure you,
A prize no less in worth: keep this man safe;
Give him all kindness: I had rather have
Such men my friends than enemies. Go on,
And see whether Brutus be alive or dead;
And bring us word unto Octavius' tent
How every thing is chanced. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 5
div.stage: Enter BRUTUS, DARDANIUS, CLITUS, STRATO, and VOLUMNIUS.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Come, poor remains of friends, rest on this rock.

sp.speaker: Clitus
sp.l: Statilius showed the torchlight, but, my lord,
He came not back: he is or ta'en or slain.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Sit thee down, Clitus: slaying is the word;
It is a deed in fashion. Hark thee, Clitus. Whispers.

sp.speaker: Clitus
sp.l: What, I, my lord? No, not for all the world.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Peace then! no words.

sp.speaker: Clitus
sp.l: I'll rather kill myself.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Hark thee, Dardanius. Whispers.

sp.speaker: Dardanius
sp.l: Shall I do such a deed?

sp.speaker: Clitus
sp.l: O Dardanius!

sp.speaker: Dardanius
sp.l: O Clitus!

sp.speaker: Clitus
sp.l: What ill request did Brutus make to thee?

sp.speaker: Dardanius
sp.l: To kill him, Clitus. Look, he meditates.

sp.speaker: Clitus
sp.l: Now is that noble vessel full of grief,
That it runs over even at his eyes.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Come hither, good Volumnius; list a word.

sp.speaker: Volumnius
sp.l: What says my lord?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Why, this, Volumnius:
The ghost of Caesar hath appeared to me
Two several times by night; at Sardis once,
And, this last night, here in Philippi fields:
I know my hour is come.

sp.speaker: Volumnius
sp.l: Not so, my lord.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Nay, I am sure it is, Volumnius.
Thou seest the world, Volumnius, how it goes;
Our enemies have beat us to the pit: Low alarums.
It is more worthy to leap in ourselves,
Than tarry till they push us. Good Volumnius,
Thou know'st that we two went to school together:
Even for that our love of old, I prithee,
Hold thou my sword-hilts, whilst I run on it.

sp.speaker: Volumnius
sp.l: That's not an office for a friend, my lord. Alarum still.

sp.speaker: Clitus
sp.l: Fly, fly, my lord; there is no tarrying here.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Farewell to you; and you; and you, Volumnius.
Strato, thou hast been all this while asleep;
Farewell to thee too, Strato. Countrymen,
My heart doth joy that yet in all my life
I found no man but he was true to me.
I shall have glory by this losing day
More than Octavius and Mark Antony
By this vile conquest shall attain unto.
So fare you well at once; for Brutus' tongue
Hath almost ended his life's history:
Night hangs upon mine eyes; my bones would rest,
That have but laboured to attain this hour. Alarum. Cry within, “Fly, fly, fly!”

sp.speaker: Clitus
sp.l: Fly, my lord, fly.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Hence! I will follow. Exeunt Clitus, Dardanius, and Volumnius.
I prithee, Strato, stay thou by thy lord:
Thou art a fellow of a good respect;
Thy life hath had some smatch of honour in it:
Hold then my sword, and turn away thy face,
While I do run upon it. Wilt thou, Strato?

sp.speaker: Strato
sp.l: Give me your hand first. Fare you well, my lord.

lg.l: Farewell, good Strato. Runs on his sword. Caesar, now be still:
I killed not thee with half so good a will.

div.stage: Alarum. Retreat. Enter OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, MESSALA, LUCILIUS, and the army.

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: What man is that?

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: My master's man. Strato, where is thy master?

sp.speaker: Strato
sp.l: Free from the bondage you are in, Messala:
The conquerors can but make a fire of him;
For Brutus only overcame himself,
And no man else hath honour by his death.

sp.speaker: Lucilius
sp.l: So Brutus should be found. I thank thee, Brutus,
That thou hast proved Lucilius' saying true.

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: All that served Brutus, I will entertain them.
Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?

sp.speaker: Strato
sp.l: Ay, if Messala will prefer me to you.

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: Do so, good Messala.

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: How died my master, Strato?

sp.speaker: Strato
sp.l: I held the sword, and he did run on it.

sp.speaker: Messala
sp.l: Octavius, then take him to follow thee,
That did the latest service to my master.

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: This was the noblest Roman of them all:
All the conspirators save only he
Did that they did in envy of great Caesar;
He only, in a general honest thought
And common good to all, made one of them.
His life was gentle, and the elements
So mixed in him that Nature might stand up
And say to all the world “This was a man!”

sp.speaker: Octavius
sp.l: According to his virtue let us use him,
With all respect and rites of burial.
Within my tent his bones to-night shall lie
Most like a soldier, ordered honourably.
So call the field to rest; and let's away,
To part the glories of this happy day. Exeunt.
